Copper(I) complexes of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene as efficient catalysts for alkyne hydroamination and azide-alkyne cycloaddition Aparajita Mukherjee a Anannya Saha b Samaresh Bhattacharya a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Inorganic Chemistry Section, Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700 032, India Department of Chemistry Inorganic Chemistry Section Jadavpur University Kolkata 700 032 India aDepartment of Chemistry, Inorganic Chemistry Section, Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700 032, India b Department of Chemical Sciences, Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Mohali, Mohali 140306, India Department of Chemical Sciences Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Mohali Mohali 140306 India bDepartment of Chemical Sciences, Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Mohali, Mohali 140306, India ⁎ Corresponding author. This paper reports the synthesis of a small group of three copper(I) complexes using 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene, abbreviated as dppbz, and their utilization as catalyst for CN bond formation reactions. Reaction of dppbz has been carried out with three different copper(I) sources. While reaction with [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4 affords [CuI(dppbz)2]ClO4 (complex 1), that with CuI and CuSCN affords di-copper complexes [{CuI(dppbz)I}2] and [{CuI(dppbz)(SCN)}2] (complexes 2 and 3) respectively. Bulk characterization on the complexes has been done by elemental (C, H, N) analysis, magnetic susceptibility measurement, and spectroscopic (IR, NMR and UV–vis) methods. Crystal structures of all three complexes have been determined. In [CuI(dppbz)2]ClO4, copper(I) is having a highly distorted tetrahedral CuP4 core. In [{CuI(dppbz)I}2] and [{CuI(dppbz)(SCN)}2], the tetrahedral CuP2I2 and CuP2SN cores are relatively less distorted. These copper complexes have been found to serve as efficient catalyst precursors for two types of CN bond formation reactions, viz. hydroamination and click reaction. Hydroamination of aryl alkynes with aryl amines has afforded selectively imine products of a single type (Markownikov product) in good yields under relatively mild condition. However, similar hydroamination with benzyl amines or alkyl amines has afforded selectively anti-Markownikov imine products. Click reaction between aryl alkynes and aryl azides yielding the cycloaddition products has also been brought about successfully with remarkable catalytic efficiency. Graphical abstract A group of three diphos-chelated copper(I) complexes were synthesized, which served as efficient catalyst for (i) hydroamination of aryl alkynes with aryl amines yielding selectively the Markownikov imine products, (ii) hydroamination of aryl alkynes with benzyl or alkyl amines affording only anti-Markownikov imine products, and (iii) click reaction between aryl alkynes and aryl azides yielding the triazoles. Image, graphical abstract Keywords 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene coordinated copper(I) complexes Catalytic alkyne hydroamination Azide-alkyne cycloaddition Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction There has been considerable attention towards utilization of copper complexes as catalyst precursor for useful chemical transformation of a wide variety of organic substrates [1–10]. The catalytic utility of copper complexes is attributable primarily to: (i) relatively easy synthesis of the targeted complexes with desired coordination environment, and (ii) the ability of the metal center to exist in, as well as interconvert between, different oxidation states. The latter aspect is of particular importance for catalytic reactions which proceed though steps involving redox changes at the metal center [6–8,10–14]. Though complexes containing copper in either of the two common oxidation states, viz. +1 and +2, are found to have wide application in catalysis, herein we decided to restrict ourselves to exploration of catalytic potential of a selected group of copper(I) complexes towards CN coupling reaction of two types, viz. hydroamination of alkynes and 1,3-dipolar azide-alkyne cycloaddition, popularly referred to as the click reaction. Hydroamination is basically a CN bond forming reaction between unsaturated hydrocarbons and amines, and is heavily utilized for the synthesis of several molecular compounds that are of significant industrial importance, such as: natural products, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, etc. [15,16]. The other highlighting aspect of hydroamination is that it does not generate any byproduct, and hence it is atom economical. This CN coupling reaction requires a metal-catalyst, the main task of which is to reduce repulsion between the two electron rich reactants, viz. the alkyne and the amine, by attracting electron density from the substrate. While several metal-catalysts are known to be employed for this reaction [17–27], utilization of copper(I)-based systems for catalytic hydroamination of alkynes, which is one primary objective of our present study, appears to have remained relatively less explored [18,22,25]. Click reaction, on the other hand, is a highly popular CN bond forming reaction that can efficiently connect two molecular species to form a new molecule, and finds wide application in organic synthesis, bio‐conjugation, drug discovery, material science, etc. [28–39]. While limited examples of copper(II)-catalyzed click reaction are available in the literature [40–42], copper(I) systems are known to catalyze such cycloaddition reaction very efficiently [43–56]. Though discovery of this remarkable azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction was made by Rolf Huisgen in 1961 [57], the spotlight actually turned to this reaction since coinage of the term “click reaction” by Barry Sharpless [58], and his notable contribution in this area along with Meldal and many others [33,37,43–56,59–62]. And there has been continuous effort towards the synthesis of new copper(I) complexes by planned variation of coordination environment around the metal center, and assess their catalytic efficiency in click reaction [43–56], and this is the other objective of our present study as well. Herein our initial aim was to synthesize a small group of copper(I) complexes using 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene, abbreviated as dppbz (see Chart 1 ), as the main ligand. This particular diphos ligand was chosen because of its soft nature and demonstrated ability to stabilize relatively lower oxidation states of transition metals [63–67]. The other notable attribute of this ligand is its uncomplicated mode of binding (shown in I, Chart 1). By virtue of having the rigid P-C6H4-P fragment, this diphos ligand is capable of forming only five-membered chelate ring (I), and unable to display any bridging mode of binding that is known for diphos ligands with flexible -(CH2) n- spacer between the phosphorus atoms [68–72]. In order to synthesize the complexes we selected three different sources of copper(I), viz. [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4, CuI and CuSCN. In this paper we describe our observation on the interaction of the dppbz ligand with the chosen copper(I) sources towards affording homoleptic and mixed-ligand complexes, their characterization, and exploration of their catalytic efficiency in alkyne hydroamination and azide-alkyne cycloaddition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4 and CuSCN were prepared by following reported procedures [73,74]. 1,2-Bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene (dppbz) and azidotrimethylsilane (TMSN3) were procured from Aldrich. All other chemicals and solvents were reagent grade commercial materials and were used as received. Microanalyses (C, H, N) were performed using a Heraeus Carlo Erba 1108 elemental analyzer. Magnetic susceptibilities were measured using a Sherwood MK-1 balance. The 1H NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl3 solution on a Bruker Avance DPX 300 NMR spectrometer using TMS as the internal standard. IR spectra were obtained on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum Two IR spectrometer as KBr pellets. Electronic spectra were recorded on a JASCO V-630 spectrophotometer. GC-MS analyses were performed using a Perkin Elmer CLARUS 680 instrument. 2.2 Computational details All DFT calculations were performed using Gaussian09 package [75]. Optimization calculations were carried out using Becke's three parameter hybrid-exchange functional with the Lee–Yang–Parr correlation function (B3LYP) based on the energetic minima results [76–78]. In the optimization calculations, Hay and Wadt basis-set LANL2DZ were used for Cu considering the pseudo core potential [79], the 6–311+G(d) basis-set was used for C, H, and N atoms [80], and all other atoms were described by 6–31G(d,p) [81]. The nature of the ground-state of each optimized-structures has been verified by their respective calculated frequencies under same level of theory as of geometry-optimization. In addition, each transition state has been located using the LST (linear synchronous transit) method, where the reaction axis was restricted at several distances and the other degrees of freedom were remained relaxed [82]. After attainment of the requisite linear transit point, the transition-states were optimized employing the default Berny algorithm implemented in the Gaussian09 code [75]. Each transition-state was supported by only one imaginary frequency. Along with this, intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations were performed for all transition-states to ensure the connectivity of these transition states to the respective reactants and products related to it. In these overall calculations related to the catalytic cycle, the polarizable conductor calculation model (CPCM) was employed for the surrounding solvent molecules, acetonitrile (ε = 37.5) giving the bulk solvent effects [83–85]. Chemcraft was used for graphics visualization [86]. 2.3 Syntheses of complexes 2.3.1 [Cu(dppbz)2]ClO4 Nitrogen gas was purged through a solution of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene (275 mg, 0.62 mmol) in chloroform (25 mL) for 5 min, and then [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4 (100 mg, 0.31 mmol) was added. The mixture was stirred at ambient temperature under nitrogen for an additional 30 min and then stirring was continued, without nitrogen purging, for 6 h, whereby a colorless solution was obtained. The solution was kept in a refrigerator for 48 h. [Cu(dppbz)2]ClO4 separated as a white crystalline solid, which was collected by filtration, washed with cold diethyl ether and dried in air. Yield: 280 mg, 87 %. Anal. Calc. for C60H48P4O4ClCu: C, 68.25; H, 4.55. Found: C, 68.09; H, 4.57 %. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3):[87] δ 6.85–7.60 (24H)*. IR (KBr, cm−1): 479, 497, 519, 624, 664, 697, 725, 740, 753, 764, 998, 1025, 1094, 1121, 1160, 1437, 1480, 1638 and 1708. Electronic spectral data: λ, nm (ε, M−1cm−1): 270* (32,900). 2.3.2 [{Cu(dppbz)I}2] To a solution of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene (236 mg, 0.53 mmol) in chloroform (25 mL) was added CuI (100 mg, 0.53 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 6 h under warm condition, whereby a light yellow solution was obtained. The solution was kept in a refrigerator for 48 h. [{Cu(dppbz)I}2] separated as a yellow crystalline solid, which was collected by filtration, washed with cold diethyl ether and dried in air. Yield: 270 mg, 81 %. Anal. Calc. for C60H48P4I2Cu2: C, 56.56; H, 3.77. Found: C, 56.66; H, 3.73 %. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.95–7.35 (48H)*. IR (KBr, cm−1): 482, 497, 518, 661, 692, 730, 742, 759, 998, 1027, 1096, 1184, 1157, 1384, 1435, 1480, 1585, 1638 and 1709. Electronic spectral data: λ, nm (ε, M−1cm−1): 296 (26,500), 243*(62,000). 2.3.3 [{Cu(dppbz)(SCN)}2] To a solution of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene (370 mg, 0.83 mmol) in chloroform (20 mL) was added to the suspension of CuSCN (100 mg, 0.83 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL). The mixture was stirred for 10 h under warm condition, whereby a light yellow solution was obtained. The solution was kept in a refrigerator for 48 h. [{Cu(dppbz)(SCN)}2] separated as a light yellow crystalline solid, which was collected by filtration, washed with cold diethyl ether and dried in air. Yield: 350 mg, 75 %. Anal. Calc. for C62H48P4S2N2Cu2: C, 65.55; H, 4.22. Found: C, 65.34; H, 4.27 %. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.10–7.40 (48H)* (Fig. S1; Supplementary material). IR (KBr, cm−1): 484, 495, 516, 662, 692, 742, 998, 1026, 1069, 1095, 1158, 1181, 1221, 1384, 1435, 1480, 1585, 1638, 1710 and 2111 (Fig. S2; Supplementary material). Electronic spectral data: λ, nm (ε, M−1cm−1): 285 (26,600), 228*(69,700) (Fig. S3; Supplementary material). 2.4 X-ray crystallography Single crystals of [Cu(dppbz)2]ClO4, [{Cu(dppbz)I}2] and [{Cu(dppbz)(SCN)}2] were harvested upon cooling their chloroform solutions, obtained directly from the synthetic reaction, in the refrigerator for 48 h. Selected crystal data and data collection parameters are given in Table S1 (Supplementary material). Data on the crystals were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer. X-ray data reduction and, structure solution and refinement were done using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 packages [88]. The structures were solved by the direct methods. 2.5 Application as catalysts 2.5.1 General procedure for hydroamination reactions In a typical run, an oven-dried 10 mL round bottom flask was charged with a known mole percent of catalyst and phenyl acetylene (1.0 mmol) and aryl amine (1.2 mmol) with acetonitrile (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at ambient temp (25 °C). After the specified time (4 h) stirring was stopped, water (20 mL) was added, and extraction with ethyl acetate (2 × 10 mL) was done. The combined ethyl acetate extract was washed with water (3 × 10 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and filtered. Solvent was removed under vacuum. The residue was dissolved in hexane and analyzed by GC–MS. 2.5.2 General procedure for click reactions In a typical run, an oven-dried 10 mL round bottom flask was charged with a selected aryl amine (1.0 mmol), t-BuONO (1.5 mmol) and TMSN3 (1.2 mmol) with acetonitrile (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 2 h. Then a known mole percent of catalyst and phenyl acetylene (1.2 mmol) was added to the mixture and the mixture was allowed to stir at ambient temperature. After the specified time stirring was stopped, water (20 mL) was added, and extraction with ethyl acetate (2 × 10 mL) was done. The combined ethyl acetate extract was washed with water (3 × 10 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and filtered. Solvent was removed under vacuum. The residue was dissolved in acetonitrile and analyzed by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The first task of this study was to synthesize a group of copper(I) complexes using 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene (dppbz) as the main ligand. In order to achieve this goal we selected three different sources of copper(I), viz. [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4, CuI and CuSCN. Reaction of [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4 with dppbz in 1:2 mole ratio in chloroform under stirring condition at ambient temperature afforded the bis-complex, [Cu(dppbz)2]+, which was isolated as its perchlorate salt in good yield. The [Cu(dppbz)2]ClO4 complex will henceforth be referred to as complex 1. It is interesting to mention that on decreasing the Cu(I):dppbz ratio to 1:1, to examine whether a mono-dppbz chelated copper(I) complex can be isolated, the same bis-complex 1 was obtained, but in much lower yield. Crystal structure of complex 1 was determined, which is shown in Fig. 1 and selected bond parameters are presented in Table S2 (Supplementary material). The CuP4 core in this complex is distorted significantly from ideal tetrahedral geometry. Similar reaction between equimolar dppbz and copper(I) iodide or copper(I) thiocyanate, both of which are polymeric in nature, afforded dinuclear complexes of type [{Cu(dppbz)I}2] (complex 2) and [{Cu(dppbz)(SCN)}2] (complex 3) respectively. It is worth mentioning here that even on increasing the Cu(I):dppbz ratio to 1:2, no bis-complex was obtained. Instead, the same dicopper complexes were obtained in similar yields. Crystal structures of complexes 2 and 3 were also determined, which are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 . While reports on the bis-complex 1 and iodo-bridged dicopper complex 2 are available in the literature [89–91], the thiocyanato-bridged dicopper complex 3 is new. In complex 2 the P2I2 environment around each copper is distorted tetrahedral in nature, and the observed bond parameters (Table S3, Supplementary material) are found to be comparable to those reported earlier [91]. Structure of complex 3 shows that the two copper centers are bridged by two thiocyanate ions that are almost linear. Each diphos ligand is chelated to one copper center forming usual five membered ring (I, MCu). Some selected bond parameters are given in Table 1 . Each copper is having a distorted tetrahedral P2NS coordination sphere around it. The CuS, CuP and CuN bond lengths are all found to be quite usual [28,89–91]. Formation of the three complexes is summarized in Scheme 1 . 3.2 Catalytic activity As outlined earlier, our second objective was to evaluate catalytic potential of the synthesized copper(I) complexes towards CN bond formation reactions of two types viz. hydroamination and azide-alkyne cycloaddition or click reaction. We began our exploration with hydroamination of phenylacetylene with 2,4,6-trimethylaniline using complex 1 as the catalyst to yield new CN coupled product(s). After extensive optimization (Table S4, Supplementary material) it was found that 2 mol% catalyst, acetonitrile as the solvent, and 4 h stirring at 25 °C furnished the CN bonded product in excellent yield (Table S4, entry 6). Considering the two different modes of addition of amine across a CC bond, viz. Markownikov and anti-Markownikov modes, four possible CN coupled products may result (Scheme 2 ) [92]. It is interesting to note that, from our reaction using complex 1 as the catalyst, only the Markownikov imine product (P 2b ; Ar = 2,4,6-trimethylphenyl) was obtained. The two di-copper complexes (2 and 3) were also found to furnish only the Markownikov imine product, but compared to the mono-copper complex (1) they show much less catalytic efficiency (Table S4, entries 12–20), and hence only the results obtained with complex 1 as the catalyst precursor are presented here. Scope of the hydroamination of alkynes is summarized in Table 2 . Using the optimized the reaction conditions, hydroamination of phenylacetylene was performed with aniline and eight substituted anilines, and the expected imines (P1 – P9 ) were obtained in very good (87 – 99 %) yields. With 2-hydroxyphenylacetylene as substrate, hydroamination was attempted with four arylamines, and the corresponding imines (P10 – P13 ) were obtained, but in lesser yields. The decrease in yield is primarily attributable to poisoning of the active catalyst through coordination of the phenolic oxygen in the arylacetylene. Besides, steric problem posed by substituents in the aniline moiety seems to be responsible also for the significantly low yields of P12 – P13 . However, when phenylacetylene having electron-donating or electron-withdrawing substituent at the para-position was used, yield of the products (P14 – P20 ) was good (90 – 96 %) with anilines bearing substituents with varying steric bulk. On moving to 1-naphthylamine, yield of the product imines (P21 – P24 ) was found to decrease again, which is due, presumably, to the larger size of 1-naphthylamine relative to the phenylamines. Here again, the imine (P22 ) from reaction with 2-hydroxyphenylacetylene was obtained in lowest yield. To gain a clear insight into the observed hydroamination reaction, the mechanistic details for the complex 1 catalyzed hydroamination of phenylacetylene with aniline were probed computationally by DFT [75]. The plausible mechanism is shown in Scheme 3 , and the associated free energy profile is depicted in Fig. 4 . DFT-optimized structures of all the relevant transition states and intermediates are presented in Fig. 5 , and their calculated Gibbs free energies are listed in Table S5 (Supplementary material). As illustrated in Scheme 3 and Fig. 4, the reaction gets initiated via coordination of phenylacetylene to the Cu(P-P) moiety, provided by the catalyst precursor, leading to formation of a π-complex (INT-1), and this marks the entry into the catalytic cycle [93]. In INT-1, the CC fragment is bonded asymmetrically to the copper-center with Cu–C distances of 2.23 and 2.08 Ả (Fig. 5). In the following CN bond-formation process two probable pathways for Markownikov addition were considered: (i) aniline approaching trans to the acetylenic hydrogen, and (ii) aniline approaching cis to the acetylenic hydrogen [94–99]. DFT results indicate that energy barrier for the C–N bond-formation via the cis approach passes through a transition state (TS1A) that lies 3.19 kcal/mol lower than the corresponding transition state (TS1B) associated with the trans approach. The possibility of CN bond-formation via anti-Markownikov addition was also examined, and the free energy barrier of the corresponding transition state (TS′-anti ) is found to be 10.79 kcal/mol higher than that of TS1A related to the Markownikov product (Fig. 6 ). This corroborates an exclusive Markownikov selectivity observed in the hydroamination reactions with arylamines. The zwitterionic intermediate INT-2A thus formed through TS-1A is endergonic by 12.47 kcal/mol with respect to INT-1 and aniline. In the next step, one possibility of subsequent intramolecular proton-transfer in INT-2A via transition state TS2′ was found to be kinetically unfavorable with an activation energy barrier of 39.41 kcal/mol, which basically rules out the probable intramolecular proton-transfer from coordinated anilinium fragment to the acetylenic carbon (C1) (Fig. 5). In this context, another possible intermolecular proton-transfer pathway could be realized by considering the assistance of another external aniline molecule in a stepwise manner [99]. In this process, the generation of the intermediate INT-3 from INT-2A and aniline is slightly exergonic by 3.23 kcal/mol. In the subsequent transition state TS2 via INT-3, the hydrogen-transfer from the N1 atom to the N2 atom of external aniline involves 4.82 kcal/mol transition state energy barrier compare to INT-3. Thus this path is energetically quite facile compared to the previously discussed one including TS2′. TS2 leads to another zwitterionic intermediate INT-4, which is 1.99 kcal/mol higher in energy than INT-3. Thus, the hydroamination product is formed through proton-donation by the external anilinium moiety involving INT-5 generated from INT-4 with subsequent loss of an aniline molecule. Finally, interaction of phenylacetylene with the copper center in INT-5 leads to elimination of the hydroaminated product in enamine form and regeneration of the catalytically active species INT-1, and the catalytic cycle thus continues. The enamine form of the product isomerizes into the thermodynamically more stable ketimine form (Fig. S4; Supplementary material). We next attempted hydroamination of four substituted phenylacetylenes with benzylamine, instead of arylamine, using the same optimized reaction conditions as before, and the results are presented in Table 3 . The expected imine products (P25 – P28 ) were all obtained in good (88 – 93 %) yields. However, it is interesting to highlight that, contrary to the earlier Markownikov imine products (P1 – P24 ) obtained from reactions with arylamines, these four imines (P25 – P28 ) are all anti-Markownikov products. Finally we tried hydroamination of the same four phenylacetylenes with cyclohexylmethanamine and again the corresponding anti-Markownikov imine products (P29 – P32 ) were obtained in decent (69 – 77 %) yields. This observed difference in the nature of hydroamination product, viz. Markownikov versus anti-Markownikov, on moving from arylamines to alkylamines is believed to result from the difference in nature of the amines that enables them to attack the acetylene moiety differently (vide infra). We have also tried to probe into the probable cause behind formation of the anti-Markownikov imine product by DFT method, taking the hydroamination of phenylacetylene with benzylamine as the representative. As depicted earlier in Scheme 3, the key step in these reactions is the initial attack by the amine on the copper-bound acetylene moiety in INT-1, which is basically the controlling factor for the following steps. In our calculations, we considered both Markownikov and anti-Markownikov interaction of benzylamine with the acetylinic carbons in INT-1 leading to formation of the corresponding transitions states (TS1ʹ and TS-1ʹʹ) and next intermediates (INT-2Bʹ and INT-2Bʹʹ), and the associated free energy diagram is shown in Fig. 7 . The activation energy barrier for the transition states TS1′ for Markownikov addition and TS1′′ for anti-Markownikov addition are 26.13 and 20.12 kcal/mol, respectively, which indicates that the hydroamination reaction of phenylacetylene with benzylamine occurs following an energetically facile anti-Markownikov pathway. DFT-optimized structures of all the five species (Fig. 7) relevant in this reaction are shown in Fig. 8 and their respective calculated Gibbs free energies are given in Table S6 (Supplementary material). Here, the primary factor behind the observed difference in the nature of hydroamination product, viz. Markownikov versus anti-Markownikov, appears to be the steric influence of the primary amines. The interesting aspect of hydroamination reaction catalyzed by our dppbz coordinated Cu(I) complexes is that, it can selectively produce anti-Markownikov imine product from reactions with aryl amines and Markownikov imine product from reactions with alkyl amines, among the four possible products (Scheme 2). Cu(I)-catalyzed hydroamination reactions are not very well known, expect three reported cases [18,22,25]. The observed catalytic efficiency of complex 1 towards the imine formation is better than that of other Cu(I)-catalysts [18–25], and comparable to that of one Cu(I)-catalyst [22]. The observed efficiency of the present group of diphos-coordinated copper(I) complexes in catalyzing hydroamination reactions, via activation of phenyl acetylene, prompted us to examine their catalytic efficiency towards another CN bond forming reaction, viz. the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition, involving the same substrate. Copper(I) species are well known to catalyze the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition between an organic azide and an alkyne, popularly known as the click reaction, to furnish 1,2,3-triazoles as the sole product [43–56]. To assess the efficiency of our present group of copper(I) complexes, we started with the cycloaddition reaction between phenylacetylene and in situ generated phenyl azide, and after screening the different reaction parameters it was observed that the best result is obtained with acetonitrile as solvent, 0.25 mol% of complex 3 as catalyst, ambient temperature and 2 h reaction time (entry 1; Table S7, Supplementary material). Using the optimized reaction condition, click reactions were performed with several substituted phenyl azides and phenylacetylenes, and the expected triazoles (P1 – P16 ) were obtained in all the cases (Table 4 ). Phenyl azides having different substituent (-H, OCH3–, -CH3, -Cl and -NO2) at the para-position, produced the corresponding trizoles (P1 – P5 ) in excellent (93 - 99 %) yields. However, for reactions with phenyl azides bearing substituents at both the ortho positions, yields of the corresponding triazoles (P6 - P9 ) were found to be slightly less, which is attributable to steric effect. Upon using 1-naphthyl azide instead of phenyl azide the yield of the product (P10 ) did not differ much. Similarly, on replacing phenylacetylene by 2-hydroxyphenylacetylene or 4-methyl/-chlorophenylacetylene, the yields of the products (P11 – P16 ) were observed to be comparable (92 – 98 %). It is interesting to note that, compared to the mono-copper complex 1, the di-copper complexes (2 and 3) turned out to be more efficient catalyst towards click reaction (Table S7, entries 2, 7 and 12). This is probably due to favorable charge delocalization over the di-copper-acetylide-azide moiety in the intermediate, formed in situ during the catalytic reaction, as observed by others [48,51,56]. Catalytic efficiency of our di-copper complexes towards click reaction is found to be better than that of many reported copper(I) catalysts [48–53,56,100–104], and comparable to that of few [54,55]. 4 Conclusions The 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene chelated copper(I) complexes (1 – 3) are found to represent a family of efficient catalysts for two types of CN coupling reactions, viz. hydroamination and 1,3-cycloaddition, via activation of phenylacetylene as the common substrate. For the hydroamination reactions the mono-copper complex 1 was found to be the best catalyst, while the di-copper complexes 2 and 3 were found to be more efficient towards catalytic click reaction. The most notable aspect of our catalytic hydroamination is the predictable site selectivity of CN coupling based on the nature of amine; anti-Markownikov coupling for aryl amines and Markownikov coupling for alkyl amines. It also worth noting that apart from this present hydroamination reaction catalyzed by our copper(I) complex, reports on copper(I)-catalyzed hydroamination is rare in the literature. For click reaction, our complex 3 appears to be a much superior catalyst, particularly in terms of lower catalyst loading and shorter reaction time. coredata.dc:description: This paper reports the synthesis of a small group of three copper(I) complexes using 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene, abbreviated as dppbz, and their utilization as catalyst for CN bond formation reactions. Reaction of dppbz has been carried out with three different copper(I) sources. While reaction with [Cu(CH3CN)4]ClO4 affords [CuI(dppbz)2]ClO4 (complex 1), that with CuI and CuSCN affords di-copper complexes [{CuI(dppbz)I}2] and [{CuI(dppbz)(SCN)}2] (complexes 2 and 3) respectively. Bulk characterization on the complexes has been done by elemental (C, H, N) analysis, magnetic susceptibility measurement, and spectroscopic (IR, NMR and UV–vis) methods. Crystal structures of all three complexes have been determined. In [CuI(dppbz)2]ClO4, copper(I) is having a highly distorted tetrahedral CuP4 core. In [{CuI(dppbz)I}2] and [{CuI(dppbz)(SCN)}2], the tetrahedral CuP2I2 and CuP2SN cores are relatively less distorted. These copper complexes have been found to serve as efficient catalyst precursors for two types of CN bond formation reactions, viz. hydroamination and click reaction. Hydroamination of aryl alkynes with aryl amines has afforded selectively imine products of a single type (Markownikov product) in good yields under relatively mild condition. However, similar hydroamination with benzyl amines or alkyl amines has afforded selectively anti-Markownikov imine products. Click reaction between aryl alkynes and aryl azides yielding the cycloaddition products has also been brought about successfully with remarkable catalytic efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Copper(I) complexes of 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)benzene as efficient catalysts for alkyne hydroamination and azide-alkyne cycloaddition
